customer_addr:
2751 Shepherd of the Hills Expressway
Branson, MO 65616

citations.narrative:
There was a 30 gallon trash can without a lid that was half full of animal waste and trash located in the building that
contained the indoor portions of the enclosures for the servals, lynx, and caracals. There was an extremely strong and
foul odor coming from the trash can that could be smelled throughout the building. There were also flies on the waste
material. Improper waste disposal can result in odor, vermin infestation, and disease hazards. The licensee must ensure
that animal waste, food waste, bedding, dead animals, and trash are collected and disposed of in a proper and timely
manner.
To be corrected by September 1, 2023.

The enclosure for two adult mute swans had a water tub that was about 7 feet long and 3 feet wide. One swan was in the
tub and could only swim in small circles in the area provided. There was not enough room for both birds to make normal
postural and social adjustments such as immersion, bathing, foraging, and swimming with adequate freedom of
movement for their well-being. The licensee must ensure that aquatic and wading birds have access to water with
sufficient surface area and depth.
To be corrected by September 7, 2023.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
An environmental enhancement plan for birds could not be produced for the inspectors at the time of the inspection. This
plan is necessary to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The licensee must develop, document, and follow a
species-appropriate plan that has been approved by the attending veterinarian. The plan must be in accordance with
AWA regulations and with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or
reference guides.
To be corrected by September 7, 2023.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The parakeet building had at least 7 mice coming out of the walls, running around on the floor, and running around the
feet of people. One mouse was observed to drink out of the parakeets’ water receptacle. Mice can contaminate bird food
and water and can harbor diseases that affect the health and well-being of birds and people. The licensee must develop a
safe and effective program for the control of insects, avian pests, and mammalian pests in and around bird enclosures.
To be corrected by September 7, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
ALICIA GRAVES, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
3.125(d) 
   
Facilities, general. 
There was a 30 gallon trash can without a lid that was half full of animal waste and trash located in the building that 
contained the indoor portions of the enclosures for the servals, lynx, and caracals. There was an extremely strong and 
foul odor coming from the trash can that could be smelled throughout the building. There were also flies on the waste 
material. Improper waste disposal can result in odor, vermin infestation, and disease hazards. The licensee must ensure 
that animal waste, food waste, bedding, dead animals, and trash are collected and disposed of in a proper and timely 
manner. 
To be corrected by September 1, 2023. 
3.153(c) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The enclosure for two adult mute swans had a water tub that was about 7 feet long and 3 feet wide. One swan was in the 
tub and could only swim in small circles in the area provided. There was not enough room for both birds to make normal 
postural and social adjustments such as immersion, bathing, foraging, and swimming with adequate freedom of 
movement for their well-being. The licensee must ensure that aquatic and wading birds have access to water with 
sufficient surface area and depth. 
To be corrected by September 7, 2023. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
An environmental enhancement plan for birds could not be produced for the inspectors at the time of the inspection. This 
plan is necessary to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The licensee must develop, document, and follow a 
species-appropriate plan that has been approved by the attending veterinarian. The plan must be in accordance with 
AWA regulations and with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or 
reference guides. 
To be corrected by September 7, 2023. 
3.158(d)

Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The parakeet building had at least 7 mice coming out of the walls, running around on the floor, and running around the 
feet of people. One mouse was observed to drink out of the parakeets’ water receptacle. Mice can contaminate bird food 
and water and can harbor diseases that affect the health and well-being of birds and people. The licensee must develop a 
safe and effective program for the control of insects, avian pests, and mammalian pests in and around bird enclosures. 
To be corrected by September 7, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
ALICIA GRAVES, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
